titleStmt.title: T.H. Lacy's Acting Edition of Victorian Plays (1848-1873) : a bibliography

165 volumes documented (but not accessible from) , covering period 1849-1917

bibl.author: [Anon. (Tom Taylor & Albert Smith)]The identification of the authors of this play is complicated: the play text describes it as 'by the authors of "Valentine and Orson", "Whittington and his Cat", "Cinderella" etc.'. Nicoll lists Tom Taylor and A.R. Smith as the authors, but has T.P. Taylor as the author of "Cinderella" and Mark Lemon as the author of "Whittington and his Cat"; further to complicate matters, Princeton University Library holds a copy of the title wrapper of the play with the following inscription: '“A” This is the Drama marked “A” referred to in the Affidavit of Charles Reade sworn before me this --th day of December.—[unsigned].' Also inscribed on t.p.: 'Fredk Bidwell'.

bibl.author: [Anon. (Tom Taylor? )]J. Stirling Coyne is listed as the author of a play of this title on the title-page of his play "My Wife's Daughter" also in this Volume. However, in Volume 1, the anonymous play, "The Philosopher's Stone" is attributed to the author of "The Vicar of Wakefield" and "Diogenes", whilst "Diogenes" (Volume 1) is attributed to the author of "Parents and Guardians". This latter is known to be by Tom Taylor, and Nicoll lists Taylor as the author also of "The Vicar of Wakefield". It is plausible that this play was co-authored by Taylor and Stirling Coyne, although they are not known to have collaborated on anything else. "Sir Roger de Coverley" (Taylor) (Volume 4) is also listed as being by the author of "Diogenes", "The Vicar of Wakefield", "The Philosopher's Stone", and "Prince Dorus".
